nodes.label: Air Quality
nodes.description: Regional Airshed: Joint governance for transboundary pollution

links.quantification: Airshed authority → coordinated action across NCR (28M people) → 40% PM2.5 from transport addressed regionally vs. 15% with city-only action
Interstate coordination → unified truck restrictions → 30% freight NO2 reduction vs. 8% with city-level policy (border leakage eliminated)
Regional standards prevent pollution havens → industries can't relocate 50km to evade controls → 25% compliance improvement
Airshed-scale planning → coal plant siting considers cumulative burden → 3 plants relocated outside NCR → 8 µg/m³ regional benefit
Jurisdictional resistance: States oppose ceding authority → constitutional barriers → 5-year political negotiation for enabling legislation
Regional action → upwind cities reduce emissions → downwind health improves → cross-city solidarity grows → political support for cooperation (reinforcing)
Requires revenue-sharing model: Cooperation only works with compensatory transfers → upwind cities need ₹500 Cr/year for action costs
Via freight electrification: Regional EV corridors → 40% truck electrification → 2 GW regional charging load → grid coordination needed
Via regional landfills: Airshed authority → joint waste facilities → 50% reduction in city-level landfill fires → PM2.5 hotspot elimination
Via equity advocacy: Regional health data exposes disparities → low-income upwind areas demand compensation → redistributive mechanisms emerge
